America is reeling from a failed war in Afghanistan, political polarisation and increasing social division. Could the superpower be in decline?

Cover image credit: AFP

node.text:
As New Yorkers commemorate the 20th anniversary of 9/11, they are also contemplating how to recover from covid-19.

After the attacks of 2001, New York came back stronger—so what lessons can its leaders learn from that success to help the city bounce back today?

Cover image credit: Gary Hershorn/Getty Images

node.title: From 9/11 to covid-19: can New York recover?

node.text:
The pandemic not only disrupted education—it also thrust technology onto a sector which historically has been slow to adopt it. Will classrooms ever be the same again?

Cover image credit: Ben Hasty/MediaNews Group/Reading Eagle via Getty Images

node.title: Covid-19: how tech will transform your kids’ education

buttons.text: Visit the COVID-19 Information Center for vaccine resources.

node.text: The race between covid-19 vaccines and variants is on. Alok Jha, The Economist’s science correspondent, and Natasha Loder, our health policy editor, discuss what this means for the future. Cover image credit: Alamy

node.title: Covid-19: can vaccines keep up with variants?

node.text: The Taliban’s swift return to power in Afghanistan has shocked the world and humiliated America. What effect will this have on the international standing of the US and on global security? Our experts answer your questions. Cover credit: AP

node.title: Afghanistan: how the Taliban weakened America

node.text:
Most governments recognise that vaccination is the fastest way out of the pandemic, but in many places hesitancy is hindering the roll-out. Should employers—or even governments—force people to have the vaccine? We answer your questions.

Cover image credit:

node.text:
The covid-19 pandemic has reinforced humanity’s dependence on modern tech, but the same tools that enable remote working are also being used to spread disinformation and perpetuate cybercrime. Ambivalence towards technology is nothing new.

Cover image credit: Scott Strazzante/The San Francisco Chronicle via Getty Images

node.text:
More than 50 countries around the world have pledged to become net zero. But what does net zero actually mean—and is it achievable?

Cover image credit: Brandon Thibodeaux/ The New York Times / Redux / eyevine

node.text:
In the past couple of weeks South Africa has witnessed the worst violence since the end of apartheid in 1994. Our correspondent in Johannesburg explains what he has seen on the streets and why the country is in crisis. 

Cover credit: Getty Images

node.title: South Africa: what's behind the riots?

node.text:
In America, the intelligence services deem far-right extremism a greater domestic threat than Islamist terrorism. The pandemic has exacerbated the spread of white supremacism and neo-Nazism.

Cover image credit: Michael Nigro/Pacific Press/LightRocket via Getty Images

node.title: Fortnite to far right: the rise of digital extremism

node.text:
Across much of the world, covid-19 restrictions are starting to ease. The Economist has crunched the data to calculate how close countries are to pre-pandemic levels of normality—but will life ever be the same again? 

Click on the link in our bio to visit our website and explore our interactive normalcy tracker. It covers 50 countries which account for 76% of the world’s population and 90% of its GDP.

Cover image credit: Lluis Gene/AFP via Getty Images

node.title: Covid-19: why your life will never be the same again

node.text:
The world’s animals and wildlife are going extinct at a greater rate than at any time in human history. Can technology help turn the tide?

Cover image credit: Yashpal Rathore/Nature Picture Library

node.title: Mass extinction: what can stop it?

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on September 20, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'The Economist explains How Marvel took over cinema and TV-the story is an epic in itself'.

node.text:
⁠Marvel’s latest film, “Shang-Chi and the Legend of the Ten Rings”, took in $90m in box-office sales in the United States and Canada over the Labour Day weekend—three times the previous Labour Day record.⁠
⁠
How did Marvel come to rule the movies?⁠
⁠
Since 1939, the studio has told hundreds of fantastic tales of superheroes battling to save the planet. But its fight to dominate pop culture involved censorship and a bankruptcy that left the company without many of its prized characters.⁠
⁠
Although other franchises have tried to emulate Marvel’s model over the past decade, none have succeeded.⁠
⁠
Marvel may seem unstoppable in the West, but it still faces plenty of battles.⁠
⁠
Click on the link in our bio to read about the comic book publisher from its rocky first decades to its super-powered success.⁠
⁠
Credit: LMK MEDIA

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on September 20, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'HOW STARGAZING COULD SAVE YOUR LIFE O'.

node.text:
Having gazed – heretically – upon very large and distant celestial bodies, Galileo Galilei realised he could use the same technology to magnify smaller terrestrial ones closer to home.⁠
⁠
Today scientists apply technology across similarly vast differences of scale. ⁠
⁠
Researchers and scientists are using similar techniques applied to starlight to model how the light of a laser penetrates breast tissue. They are searching for small shifts in the wavelength of light that may signify the tell-tale presence of calcium deposits created by breast cancer. ⁠
⁠
This method of cancer detection has the potential to be more accurate.⁠
⁠
Tap the link in our bio to read @1843mag's look at how stargazing is being harnessed to save lives.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on September 20, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Is America Inc getting less dynamic, less global and more concentrated? New business applications, 000 United States 600 500 400 300 200 2015 16 100 17 18 Source: US Census Bureau 19 0 20 21 The Economist'.

node.text:
There are concerns that American capitalism is in demise. So we tested all three hypotheses and found that these rumours are exaggerated. ⁠
⁠
Start with dynamism. As the first chart shows, in the first six months of 2021 around 2.8m new firms were born, 60% more than in the same period in pre-pandemic 2019.⁠
⁠
Many are small enterprises created by people stuck at home during lockdowns. And America’s biggest startups are thriving too. ⁠
⁠
The number of unicorns—private companies valued at over $1bn—has also shot up (swipe to chart two) and since January 2020 the average number of monthly IPOs has risen three-fold, to around 80 (see chart three). ⁠
⁠
In the same period American firms have raised nearly $350bn, more than in the preceding seven years added together.⁠
⁠
Swipe through these charts, which prove that since the arrival of covid-19, America Inc has been anything but stagnant. ⁠
⁠
Click on the link in our bio to read why America Inc is alive and kicking.

New business applications, 000 United States 600 500 400 300 200 2015 16 100 17 18 Source: US Census Bureau 19 0 20 21 The Economist'.
Photo by The Economist on September 20, 2021.
Photo by The Economist on September 20, 2021.

Photo by The Economist on September 20, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Is America Inc getting less dynamic, less global and more concentrated? Real private non-residential domestio investment United States, % change on previous quarter, annualised* 20 10 -10 85 90 95 2000 05 1980 Source: US Census Bureau *Four-quarter moving average -20 10 15 21 The Economist'.
Photo by The Economist in Paris, France. May be an image of 1 person and aircraft.

node.text:
The announcement by America, Australia and Britain of a new security pact (AUKUS), has left France humiliated and irate.⁠
⁠
The deal torpedoed Australia’s $90bn submarine contract with France, which was signed in 2016.⁠
⁠
The moment that Jean-Yves Le Drian, the French foreign minister, on September 16th described the deal as a “stab in the back”, the anger in Paris was plain.⁠
⁠
The next day, the French recalled their ambassadors to Washington, DC and that to Australia, for the first time since the 1790s. ⁠
⁠
The country has been angered by, what one source calls the “extreme duplicity and betrayal of good faith” on the part of countries it considers to be close allies.⁠
⁠
Tap the link in our bio to find out what lesson France will likely learn from this.⁠
⁠
Credit: Ludovic Marin/Pool/abacapress

buttons.text: Visit the COVID-19 Information Center for vaccine resources.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on September 20, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Israel's experience shows that timely booster jabs can counter the next wave of infections Naftali Bennett'.

node.text:
Life began to get back to normal in Israel—then the Delta variant arrived. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Writing for The Economist, the country’s prime minister Naftali Bennett argues that responding with booster vaccines was justified.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
“When many experts advised us that we should focus on the small proportion of non-vaccinated people before delivering boosters, we decided the third jabs were necessary to safeguard the public’s confidence in the vaccines,” says Mr Bennett.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
“Waiting too long to administer third doses risks squandering gains already made through vaccination and eroding valuable public trust. Israel’s experience shows that timely booster jabs can counter the next wave of infections.” ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
As well as this, the third dose “has proven itself successful against the Delta variant,” says Mr Bennett, and protects people, the economy and social wellbeing. To read what Israel has learnt from giving booster jabs, and what lessons Mr Bennett believes his experience offers to other countries, click on the link in our bio.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Illustration: @dan.will

node.text:
The Gates Foundation is the world’s most powerful charity. ⁠
⁠
It is the second-biggest donor to the World Health Organisation, behind only the American government. ⁠
⁠
In fact, if the foundation were a government, it would be the 12th-biggest disburser of foreign aid, between Italy and Switzerland.⁠
⁠
Bill Gates has pioneered a data-driven, tech-based approach to philanthropy. His divorce from Melinda French Gates, who “humanised” the foundation, will set it on a novel course.⁠
⁠
Click the link in our bio to read about the rise and immense influence of the Gates Foundation, and explore where it is going next.⁠
⁠
Illustration: @mrkhrrs_

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist in Australia. May be an image of ocean and text that says 'International The strategic reverberations of the AUKUS deal will be big and lasting'.

node.text:
Just occasionally, you can see the tectonic plates of geopolitics shifting in front of your eyes.⁠
⁠
The unveiling last week of a trilateral defence pact between Australia, the United Kingdom and the United States (AUKUS) is providing one of those rare occasions.⁠
⁠
AUKUS envisages a wide range of diplomatic and technological collaboration, from cybersecurity to artificial intelligence.⁠
⁠
But Australia scrapping a contract, worth billions of dollars, signed in 2016 with France for diesel-electric submarines has infuriated France. ⁠
⁠
On September 17th President Emmanuel Macron withdrew France’s ambassadors from Washington and Canberra (though not London).⁠
⁠
Yet in Australian eyes the developments that led to AUKUS were largely made in China, tap the link in the bio to find out why.⁠
⁠
Credit: Getty Images

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist in Moscow, Russia. May be an image of 1 person, standing and text that says 'Europe Vladimir Putin is still rattled by Alexei Navalny HaBaлbHomy aлeKceю Bo6oAy'.

node.text:
For Vladimir Putin, Alexei Navalny is proving hard to crush.⁠
⁠
Russia's president has tried to poison him, imprisoned him, outlawed his anti-courruption foundation, chased his comrades out of the country and barred his allies from standing in elections.⁠
⁠
And yet, after all this, Mr Navalny and his movement are still featuring at the heart of the elections to Russia’s Duma (its parliament) on September 19th.⁠
⁠
The Kremlin has been hoping that most Russians will take no interest in the election. But the opposite may be happening. ⁠
⁠
What exactly is “smart voting” and why is Mr Navalny promoting it? Click the link in our bio to find out. ⁠
⁠
Credit: AP Photo/Alexander Zemlianichenko, File

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist in Beijing, China. May be an image of text that says 'Business The vanishing allure of doing business in China'.

node.text:
For many multinational firms the lure of China remains irresistible. But the perils are catching up with the promise. ⁠
⁠
Western firms operate in China on sufferance and one day the country may seek to replace them, says our Schumpeter columnist.⁠
⁠
In the past week alone Xi Jinping’s government has taken steps to reduce barriers between tech giants Alibaba and Tencent and reportedly ordered the break-up of Alipay. The question on everyone’s lips, one veteran China watcher says, is “who might be next?”⁠
⁠
Tap the link in our bio to learn how Mr Xi’s war on flamboyance threatens the most lucrative end of the Chinese market for European luxury brands. ⁠
⁠
Illustration: @brett.ryder.illustration

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on September 19, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, animal and text that says 'Science technology How to toilet train your cow and save the planet'.

node.text:
Scientists have a new strategy to fight climate change: toilet training cows.⁠
⁠
Cow urine produces ammonia, which in turn becomes nitrous oxide, which is a potent greenhouse gas. ⁠
⁠
A German scientist has developed a three-stage process to help cows master toilet training. As cows are intelligent animals, it has proved quite successful. ⁠
⁠
Of the 16 calves, 11 were considered successfully toilet-trained by the end of it. That performance is roughly comparable to that of human children. ⁠
⁠
Tap on the link in our bio to read more.⁠
⁠
Credit: Getty Images

node.text:
Will America’s vaccine mandates work? On “The Economist Asks” podcast host Anne McElvoy speaks to Dr Scott Gottlieb, the former commissioner of America’s Food and Drug Administration.⁠
⁠
On the podcast, Mr Gottlieb describes how political polarisation complicated the pandemic response in America. The author of “Uncontrolled Spread” also assesses how future epidemics can be squashed earlier and the efficacy of booster shots.⁠
⁠
To also hear how he cooks his steak for safety and taste, click the link in our bio to listen to “The Economist Asks”

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist in Greece. May be a black-and-white image of 1 person, playing a musical instrument, guitar and indoor.

node.text:
The opening of the theme tune to “Zorba the Greek” is quite possibly the most famous two­-note phrase in post-war European music.⁠
⁠
Yet five years after “Zorba”, Mikis Theodorakis, the composer, is living in internal exile in his homeland, Greece. His music has been banned, it was said, for arousing passions and causing strife among the people. ⁠
⁠The Greek colonels who had seized power in 1967 judged his compositions to be in the service of communism. He wrote a poem called “I had three lives”. ⁠
⁠
He used the theme of three lives in his work to braid together all the threads that gave his life meaning: boundless artistic energy, heroic political struggle and private love and sorrow.⁠
⁠
Mikis Theodorakis died on September 2nd, aged 96. To read about the day when his three lives came together, tap the link in our bio.⁠
⁠
Credit: Photopress Archiv/Keystone⁠
